entry.title: 移动设备故事设计的最佳实践指南
entry.content:
介绍

借助SAP分析云，设计人员和开发人员在创建故事时可以使用大量灵活的功能。然而，考虑这些复杂的故事可能对​​移动设备​​中的用户体验和运行性能产生的影响是十分重要的。

​​在本篇博客中，我们将重点介绍一些最佳实践指南，供设计人员和开发人员在为移动设备创作故事时参考。

最佳实践

为了提供流畅且用户友好的体验，设计人员和开发人员可以参考一些最佳实践指南。这些指南可分为三部分：

  • 理解移动设备硬件规格
  • 故事简化（对象与高级特性）​
  • 移动设备上的测试与验证

理解移动设备硬件规格

设计人员和开发人员应该熟悉SAP分析云的移动硬件规格。这是因为根据整个业务中可用的设备，应遵循不同的最佳实践指南。以下是每个设备的一些推荐的最佳实践指南：

设备内存大小（iPad和iPhone）

最大页面数量（推荐）

iPad 单页单元权重总量（推荐）

iPhone 单页单元权重总量（推荐）

3GB

3

2.5

2.5

4GB

4

3.0

2.5

6GB

5

4.0

2.5

8GB

7

4.5

3.5

16GB 

10

5.0

N/A

故事简化（对象与高级特性）​

设计人员和开发人员应该了解在移动设备上向消费者展示哪些信息是重要的。因为与笔记本电脑不同，移动设备的屏幕尺寸和设备内存有限。

技巧1. 降低仪表盘整体复杂度​

从便利性角度出发，将所有信息整合至单一故事颇具吸引力。然而，此举可能导致​​信息过载​​，并​​使移动设备体验复杂化​​。因为页面数量与对象的组合会增加故事大小，进而导致运行处理时间的增加。

注意：当与设计数据相关的小部件数量和页面数量超过建议数量时，设计时会发出警告。

  • · 限制单页上数据相关小部件的数量：建议将这些内容分散到多个页面中。对于流式布局面板或响应式布局，可以使用响应规则配置来根据设备隐藏特定的小部件。
  • 限制故事页的数量：建议同时限制单个故事板内的页面总数。创建更精简的故事，并利用​​故事之间的超链接​​实现跨故事导航。

技巧2. 限制“高消耗”可视化对象的数量

鉴于移动设备内存普遍低于Web端，且不同移动设备内存容量差异显著，​​因此严格控制内存密集型微件的数量十分重要​​。各微件类型的单位权重值详情可参阅SAP帮助门户文档。

以下为高消耗微件示例：

  • ​​地理可视化对象​​
    • ​​表
    • ​​时间序列统计图​​
    • ​​自定义微件

注意：对于​​地理可视化对象，还有进一步的建议，即​​每页至多包含一个​​地理可视化对象​​，​​且在该可视化对象中限制图层数（不超过三个）。

注意：一个故事中筛选器的数量能会影响移动设备上的性能

技巧3. 限制复杂脚本的使用

使用优化体验，有许多可用的 API，允许开发者创建开箱即用的自定义应用或工作流，这意味着低效的脚本或复杂的脚本会对移动设备体验产生影响，原因在于其会增大处理负载并引发移动设备闪退。

在各种移动设备上进行测试和验证

​注意：以上提示均属最佳实践指南。鉴于移动设备硬件配置差异显著，必须逐台验证使用体验。

技巧1. 预览和测试

故事中的设备预览功能是验证多设备适配效果的实用工具，但若需确保界面响应灵敏、体验流畅易用，物理设备预览与测试环节依然至关重要。

技巧2. 性能和内存验证

作为技巧1的扩展，侧重点在于​​要求跨多种设备的（如3, 4, 6, 8+ GB内存），对故事进行充分测试​​。这能为用户​​规避内存溢出（OOM）问题提供额外保障​​。

结论

借助这些最佳实践指南，设计人员和开发人员将能够优化他们的故事以供移动设备使用，确保流畅且用户友好的体验

随着 SAP分析云的 2024 年第四季度(Q4)季度发布更新(QRC)​​，SAC移动设备iOS应用将对兼容的故事启用精简版查看器。该技术将​​显著降低在移动设备上打开故事时的运行内存消耗​​。

原文链接：Best Practice Guide for Designing Stories for Mobi... - SAP Community

原作者：Kapil, Tunir

entry.title: How to retrieve multiple tables at once using SAP Gateway Service Builder
entry.content:
Using SAP Gateway Service Builder, I am implementing Association and GET_EXPANDED_ENTITYSET methods based on the following article.

https://www.sapyard.com/odata-and-sap-netweaver-gateway-part-iv-association-and-navigation-in-odata-service/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hTNclt8sM2c
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K0yuFRQRygY&list=PLl_MEz33D2N0NvudI_oxOuRW5XMamXe5l&index=28

In the article, both the retrieval of the Principal table (TABLE1) and the Dependent table (TABLE2) are described using GET_EXPANDED_ENTITYSET. However,
when I actually execute the API with $expand, GET_EXPANDED_ENTITYSET is executed multiple times.
The retrieval of Principal data is successful, but I am unable to retrieve Dependent data.
Please tell me the correct implementation method for GET_EXPANDED_ENTITYSET.
Also, is it normal for GET_EXPANDED_ENTITYSET to be executed multiple times with a single API execution?


The following is other information.

・sourcecode

DATA: BEGIN OF ts_deep_entity.
INCLUDE TYPE /<package>/<mpc>=>ts_table1.
DATA: table2Set TYPE /<package>/<mpc>=>tt_table2,
END OF ts_deep_entity.

DATA:it_deep_entity LIKE TABLE OF ts_deep_entity,
wa_deep_entity LIKE LINE OF it_deep_entity.
DATA: it_info TYPE /<package>/<mpc>=>tt_table1,
it_item TYPE /<package>/<mpc>=>tt_table2.

CASE IV_ENTITY_SET_NAME.
WHEN 'table1Set'.
SELECT * FROM /<package>/table1
INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE @IT_deep_entity.
LOOP AT it_deep_entity INTO wa_deep_entity.
SELECT * FROM /<package>/table2 INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE @IT_item.
" WHERE parentid= @its_deep_entity-id.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING it_item TO wa_deep_entity-table2Set.
ENDLOOP.

CALL METHOD me->/iwbep/if_mgw_conv_srv_runtime~copy_data_to_ref
EXPORTING
is_data = it_deep_entity
CHANGING
cr_data = ER_ENTITYSET.
WHEN 'table2Set'.

• When checking the value of IV_ENTITY_SET_NAME in the debugger,
the first execution returns the Principal EntitySet value, and subsequent executions return the Dependent EntitySet value.
Additionally, GET_EXPANDED_ENTITYSET is executed once for each row in the Principal table (Table1) plus one extra execution.

entry.title: Re: Canadian Tax Subcondition Type - SD
entry.content:
Table A053 stores condition records for taxes using jurisdiction codes, including condition types like JRC1–JRC4. In systems with “Test Data” enabled, SAP preloads this table with jurisdiction codes and tax rates, allowing automatic tax determination—even for manually configured condition types. Without test data, A053 is empty, so the system can’t find matching records unless you create them manually.

As you would know, each condition type (e.g. JRC1) must be assigned an access sequence that includes table A053. To check this access sequence, go to V/07 and verify that the access sequence for JRC1–JRC4 includes A053. If it is missing, you can create a new one and add A053. If you created a new access sequence and added A053, ensure that you assigned this new access sequence to A053 in v/06. Finally, maintain condition record in vk11 so that, A053 will populate with the necessary entries.

entry.title: Join Us at SAP Connect 2025 – October 6–8 in Las Vegas!
entry.content:
We’re excited to invite you to SAP Connect 2025, taking place from October 6–8, 2025, in Las Vegas, Nevada. 

This new flagship event brings together business leaders, line-of-business practitioners, data experts, and SAP partners for three inspiring days of innovation, insights, and meaningful exchange — all centered around the power of integrated business transformation. 

What is SAP Connect? 

SAP Connect replaces former solution-specific events like SAP Spend Connect Live and SAP SuccessConnect, bringing them together under one unified umbrella — but with a clear solution area focus: 

  • Sessions are organized into five dedicated solution tracks (e.g., procurement, HR, finance, data & analytics), 
  • Each track is tailored to the needs of its audience and physically separated for depth and relevance, 
  • Keynotes will bring everyone together, while breakouts stay close to your day-to-day challenges and opportunities. 

This is a solution-led event, designed to help organizations explore how SAP technologies drive real-world business outcomes. 
 

Why Attend? 

  • Discover the latest innovations in SAP’s end-to-end suite 
  • Learn from customer success stories and SAP experts 
  • Join hands-on sessions tailored to your solution area 
  • Connect with peers, SAP leaders, and partners 
  • Be part of shaping the future of business transformation 
     

Who Should Attend? 

Whether you're: 

  • A procurement leader, HR practitioner, finance expert, or data strategist, 
  • A line-of-business (LoB) decision-maker, 
  • A C-level executive looking for strategic insights, 
  • Or a partner working across industries — 

SAP Connect 2025 is for you. 

There will also be a dedicated Executive Program for senior leaders, along with networking opportunities, customer success stories, and hands-on sessions. 

Event Details: 

Date: October 6–8, 2025 
Location: Las Vegas, NV, USA 
Registration: https://www.sap.com/events/connect.html 

Customer registration is already open. 

Don’t miss this opportunity to be part of SAP’s most focused business innovation event yet. 
We look forward to welcoming you in Las Vegas!

entry.title: Re: Delivery should not be Invoiced
entry.content: Configuration Options Business Rule Setup Configure delivery date requirements through transaction rules. You can set up rules that require delivery dates for order confirmations and ship notices [1]. When enabled, suppliers must provide delivery dates on order confirmations and ship notices before proceeding with billing processes. Validation Rule Implementation Implement validation rules that check delivery date fields before allowing invoice creation. The system can be configured to prevent invoice processing when required delivery information is missing [1]. Technical Implementation Approaches User Exit Enhancement Create a user exit or enhancement point that validates the delivery document before posting. This would involve: Adding validation logic to check if the Actual Date field is populated Preventing the billing process from continuing if the validation fails Displaying appropriate error messages to guide users Form Template Configuration Configure form templates with validation settings that prevent forms from being created or processed without required date information [2]. This ensures data completeness before document submission. Recommended Settings Enable the rule "Require delivery dates for order confirmations and ship notices" to mandate that suppliers provide delivery dates [1]. This prevents incomplete delivery documents from progressing to the billing stage. Set up tolerance checks and validation rules that verify delivery date completion before allowing subsequent transaction processing. [1] https://help.sap.com/docs/business-network-for-supply-chain/business-network-buyer-administration/order-confirmation-and-ship-notice-rules [2] https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-performance-and-goals/implementing-and-managing-360-reviews/360-form-template-settings

entry.title: Re: Departure country from Supplier for Third party sales
entry.content: One option is to create a virtual plant in SAP with the supplier’s country as its location. Assign this plant to third-party items so SAP picks up the correct departure country. This is a workaround but can be effective if you have a limited number of suppliers; else, the other option is to go with custom validation via BAdI SD_TAX_DETERMINE to override the departure country during billing.

entry.title: LMS notification reporting: Extend reporting possibilities
entry.content:
Hi all, 

We are looking for solutions to create a clean report to get an overview of all mails that were sent about a certain class or item. Currently it is not possible as there is no link on the tables between the mails and the classes or items.

We have tried to do it via a "catch all" filtering based on the subject of the mails, but this is not waterproof. So we have launched an improvement request to create an extra field in the table that stores the link to a class and or item. 

If you think this would support your use case(s), please support our enhancement request!

Reporting: Add field in database PA_ARCHIVE_MAIL with link to ITEM or CLASS

entry.title: Re: Tax recorded in entity where the vendor is not where...
entry.content:
Consider the below options

  • If your tax is related to withholding, you can configure extended withholding tax to post to a different company code. However, this doesn’t apply to VAT or sales tax scenarios.
  • Set up a clearing account in Cocode1 that temporarily holds the tax. Then, use a custom program or allocation cycle to transfer the tax to Cocode2 based on expense distribution.
  • Explore going for custom validation via BAdI like BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT or BADI_FI_TAX_POSTING where the logic can be to detect intercompany scenario and Redirect tax line to the company code of the expense (Cocode2)

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public, Which doc. type is allowed for posting interco billing doc. request?
entry.content:
Dear,

We found that it’s possible to post expenses, salaries via Excel template  (App : Import Supplier Invoices,  But it’s not possible to generate the IC billing request directly from the expense posting. Reassign cost and revenues are necessary, before generating the billing request. This is a manual step.

Currently we are investigating a different way to post the expenses.

There are restrictions for the intercompany billing: it supports following posting types:

Timesheet (including Intercompany contingent worker through cost center)
Cancellation of Timesheet
Activity allocation (including Margin Posting)
Cancellation of Activity Allocation
Reassign/Repost Costs and Revenues
Settlement Posting
Concur Posting
Universal Allocation
Cancellation of Universal Allocation
Service Order Confirmation
Cancellation of Service Order Confirmation
Controlling Assessment
Cancellation of Controlling Assessment

In App: Generate intercompany billing request app, we get the error: "failed to create intercompany billing document request, there are no postings , cannot create billing document request"

Could you please assist how to post a intercompany billing document, and what can be its document type?

Thank you.
Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Seamless Planning with Datasphere & SAC: Seamless Planning in the Cloud?
entry.content:
@Xiao_Qi_Png , Yes, the users need to have an account in both SAC and Datasphere tenants. Since the planning data in SAC needs to be written to the relevant space in Datasphere, it is logical to use the same user id for access control instead of a system/DB users (generally these users have no access restriction). 

Please refer to "Access, roles, security" section of this blog from Max 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/seamless-planning-integration-between-sap-analytics-cloud-and-sap/ba-p/13877679

entry.title: Why I'm Attending SAP TechEd 2025 Virtually and Top Picks
entry.content:
If you are an SAP fan like me, you know that SAP TechEd is the place to be. As always, it is packed with innovation, insights, and forward-thinking sessions.  Whether you are into SAP Integration Suite wizardry, BTP magic, or just geeking out over the latest in AI, cloud, and developer tools—this is our Super Bowl. 

This year, you can build AI agents with Joule and SAP AI services, unlock real-time insights with SAP Business Data Cloud, automate smarter with SAP’s full developer toolchain, and modernize fast using SAP Integration Suite. Plus, it’s an amazing chance to connect with the global dev community that's shaping what’s next for the SAP ecosystem.

This year, I’m attending virtually—and no, it’s not because I’m afraid of airport security or can’t find my suitcase (okay… maybe just a little). It's because SAP TechEd virtual is packed with value, zero travel hassle, and 100% flexibility.

Here’s why I'm fired up for the virtual experience:

Access to World-Class Content

From keynote deep dives to strategy talks and road maps, SAP TechEd brings cutting-edge topics to your screen—including AI, BTP, S/4HANA, and low-code/no-code development. And yes, you can pause the session to refill your coffee. Try doing that at an in-person keynote!

It is Built for Builders
Whether you’re a developer, architect, or just SAP-curious, the virtual platform is designed to help you dig deep. Personalized tracks, live chats, and digital networking—it’s all there. 

On Your Schedule
No need to block out travel days or rearrange your week. Attend sessions live or catch replays when it works for you. Your future SAP knowledge base will thank you.

Did I mention it’s FREE?
No flights, no hotels, no expenses. Just you, your device, and an all-access pass to SAP’s most important tech event of the year.

My SAP TechEd top picks

This year, I’m especially excited about sessions that show how AI is not just a buzzword—but a real accelerator for consultants, developers, and users alike. Here are my top 3 picks you won’t want to miss:

1.- ST123v | Transforming how people work with Joule technology
Explore how upcoming innovations, third-party integrations, and customization options from Joule are changing the way we interact with SAP. Get insider insights into what’s powering the new agentic AI UI—and how it’s reshaping user experiences. AI is no longer the future—it's the co-pilot of the present.

2.- AD820v | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions
See what’s next for SAP Build: enhanced pro developer tools, deeper Joule integration, and improved extensibility for LoB apps. All designed to support clean core principles and boost developer productivity.

3.- ST112v | AI and the Future of Product and UX on Web and Mobile
Joule isn’t just for consultants—it’s transforming the user experience too. This session dives into how embedded AI is enhancing UX for SAP Business Suite. Whether you're designing mobile apps or web interfaces, you'll see how users are getting more relevant, more personalized, and more intuitive experiences—and how you can be part of creating them.

So if you're thinking of joining—stop thinking and just register now 👉https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin.html

 

See you (virtually) at TechEd! 😉

entry.title: Re: Create SAP S/4HANA External GL Account Hierarchy within SAP Datasphere using standard CDS Views
entry.content:
@JoelleS the values of all dimension columns that do not correspond to the Node Type, have to be NULL. 

See this part in the following blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/modeling-a-basic-hierarchy-with-directory-in-sap-datasphere/ba-p/13575652 

"Take the first line of the table in Figure 6 for example: the Node Type is PRODUCT_CATEGORY.  This means that the column Product ID is not relevant. This column must be of value NULL. If you would for example fill the column Product ID with value JUICE_1, this would also aggregate all bookings of JUICE_1 into hierarchy node 2 (MILK), leading to wrong assignments and aggregated values."

entry.title: Re: Split Customer Invoice and Tax amount
entry.content:
By default, SAP posts the gross amount to the customer account and splits the revenue and tax on the credit side. But your requirement is to split the debit side as well.

Some of the options which you can explore on the configuration side are

 

  • Create a separate customer reconciliation account for tax amounts. Post the tax portion to this account using a substitution rule or user exit during document posting.
  • Define a substitution rule in transaction GGB1 for the FI module.
  • If you're using New GL, activate document splitting for tax items. This allows SAP to split tax amounts across different account assignments.
  • If nothing suits the Business requirement, use a BADI or user exit like BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT or EXIT_SAPLF048_001 to add the required logic during FI posting

entry.title: SAP HANA XSA x509 Certificate UAA token flow?
entry.content:
I'm trying to authenticate with the UAA service using the "x509" certificate "mTLS" flow (or to use a certificate instead of a client secret if that is possible).

I've created a Node JS application that serves as a OData service secured by the UAA service.

I've set in the xs-security.json:

{
"xsappname": "App",
"oauth2-configuration": {
"credential-types": ["x509"]
}...

The mta.yaml:

resources:
  - name: UAA-service
    type: com.sap.xs.uaa-space
    parameters:
      path: xs-security.json
      service-plan: application
      config:
        xsappname: mAapp
        oauth2-configuration:
          credential-types:
            - x509

uaa.oid.enablex509 is set to true in the xsuaaserver.ini

However, getting information from https://[hostname.com]:39032/uaa-security/.well-known/openid-configuration shows that the token endpoint only supports client_secret_basic, client_secret_post and private_key_jwt:

{
  "issuer": "http://.../UAA/oauth/token",
  "authorization_endpoint": "https://...:39032/uaa-security/oauth/authorize",
  "token_endpoint": "https://...:39032/uaa-security/oauth/token",
  "token_endpoint_auth_methods_supported": [
    "client_secret_basic",
    "client_secret_post",
    "private_key_jwt"
  ],
  "token_endpoint_auth_signing_alg_values_supported": [
    "RS256",
    "HS256"
  ],
  "userinfo_endpoint": "https://...:39032/uaa-security/userinfo",
  "jwks_uri": "https://...:39032/uaa-security/token_keys",
  "end_session_endpoint": "https://...:39032/uaa-security/logout.do",
  "scopes_supported": [
    "openid",
    "profile",
    "email",
    "phone",
    "roles",
    "user_attributes"
  ],
  "response_types_supported": [
    "code",
    "code id_token",
    "id_token",
    "token id_token"

  ],

  ],

  ],
  "claim_types_supported": [
    "normal"
  ],
  "claims_supported": [
    "sub",
    "user_name",
    "origin",
    "iss",
    "auth_time",
    "amr",
    "acr",
    "client_id",

    "exp",
    "iat",
    "jti",
    "rev_sig",
    "cid",
    "given_name",
    "family_name",
    "phone_number",
    "email"
  ],

    "en-US"
  ],
  "code_challenge_methods_supported": [
    "S256",
    "plain"

If I run my XSA node.JS application with only "x509" enabled, I get an error:

export default function ReadAttachmentAsBase64(context) {

entry.title: Re: Provision Entries for Fiscal year - TDS not effecting...
entry.content:
By default, SAP posts TDS during invoice or payment transactions. But for year-end provisions, you need to simulate a liability without an actual invoice—this requires:

  • Special GL indicator for vendor-side posting
  • Correct withholding tax type for provision
  • Document type and posting logic that splits the entry between vendor and tax GLs

On the config side, Define Withholding Tax Type for Provisions, Create Withholding Tax Code and Assign Withholding Tax to Vendor Master and finally, execute f-51 for manual journal entry

entry.title: Re: A record needs to change during go-live over DNS Switch
entry.content:
Migrating VMs while retaining the same hostname and updating DNS records is a common scenario. While there might not be a specific SAP Knowledge Base (KB) article or blog that addresses this exact scenario, the general steps involved can be outlined as follows:

  1. Preparation:

    • Ensure that you have a complete backup of your existing VMs and data.
    • Document the current DNS settings and A records for the VMs.

  2. VM Migration:

    • Set up the target VMs in Azure with the same specifications as the source VMs.
    • Install the necessary SAP software and configurations on the target VMs.

  3. Hostname Configuration:

    • Configure the target VMs to use the same hostname as the source VMs. This can typically be done during the VM setup process or by modifying the hostname settings in the operating system.

  4. DNS Update:

    • During the cutover, you will need to update the DNS records. This involves removing the existing A records for the source VMs and creating new A records for the target VMs with the same hostnames.
    • Ensure that the DNS server is properly configured to handle the new A records.

  5. Testing:

    • After the DNS update, verify that the hostname resolution is working correctly and that the target VMs are accessible using the intended hostnames.
    • Perform thorough testing to ensure that all SAP applications and services are functioning as expected on the target VMs.

  6. Finalization:

    • Once testing is complete and everything is verified to be working correctly, finalize the migration process.
    • Monitor the system closely for any issues that may arise post-migration.

entry.title: Re: Additional label printing in the stage of "Release" o...
entry.content:
To enable label printing at the release stage of a production order in SAP S/4HANA; in addition to the existing setup at Goods Receipt (GR) via movement type 101, you’ll need to configure an additional output determination trigger tied to the order release status (REL). In S/4HANA, output determination is handled via BRF+

Define a new output type or reuse the existing label output type. Configure a new condition rule that triggers when Production order status changes to REL and Order type, plant, or material match desired criteria

Go to Manage Output Types app or transaction OPK8. Assign the label output type to the production order. Ensure the form and print program are correctly linked

In BRF+, define a rule that checks:

  • Order status = REL
  • Order type = PP01 (or relevant)
  • Plant = 1000 (or relevant)

Set the action to trigger label print output.

Finally, use user exit or BADI like WORKORDER_UPDATE or BADI_PP_PRINT to trigger label printing. Inside the enhancement, check for status change to REL and call the label print program.

entry.title: Re: Missing Sales Order Reference after integration to S4...
entry.content:
The fact that your planned order in IBP retains the sales order reference but loses it upon transfer to S/4HANA suggests a gap in the inbound mapping logic during the planned order creation in S/4.

It could be that when IBP transfers a planned order to S/4HANA via Real-Time Integration (RTI), the reference to the sales order is not automatically populated in the “Assignment” tab unless:

  • The account assignment category is correctly set (typically E for sales order)
  • The sales order and item number are explicitly passed and mapped during inbound processing
  • The planned order creation logic in S/4 recognizes and links the reference fields

Recommended approach would be to enhance the inbound BAdI CIF_PLANNED_ORDER_INBOUND allows you to enrich planned order data during inbound processing from IBP.

entry.title: Re: Differentiating DSA Violations from Common Moderation Issues
entry.content:
Understanding the difference between DSA violations and common content moderation issues is key to complying with digital regulations and ensuring fair online governance. The Digital Services Act (DSA), implemented by the European Union, introduces legal obligations for digital platforms, especially Very Large Online Platforms (VLOPs), to manage systemic risks and illegal content transparently.

A DSA violation typically refers to a failure in meeting the law’s requirements—such as not providing transparency in moderation decisions, failing to allow user appeals, or not removing illegal content (e.g., hate speech, misinformation, child exploitation material) within a reasonable timeframe. These violations can result in audits, penalties, or platform restrictions.

In contrast, common moderation issues are day-to-day operational concerns that platforms handle internally. These might include spam, offensive language, off-topic posts, or minor breaches of community guidelines. While these are important to manage, they don’t necessarily equate to legal noncompliance unless they scale or are handled inconsistently without transparency.

What sets DSA violations apart is the legal accountability and systemic nature of the breach. For instance, if a platform fails to offer a mechanism for appealing content removal, that’s a DSA compliance issue, not just a moderation oversight.

To stay compliant, platforms should implement clear content policies, publish transparency reports, and provide appeal processes. Moderators must be trained to distinguish between internal policy violations and potential legal infractions under the DSA.

entry.title: Re: Do you use the "Group Members" assignment in a Group...
entry.content:
Answer from SAP:

Currently, managing group membership (add/remove) for ALAG groups is not supported via the Admin Console UI, you can only see the group members. This scenario with the managing is supported exclusively through the IdDS SCIM Groups API.

While we understand the convenience of having this capability in the UI, this functionality has not yet been implemented. However, it is under consideration for future improvements. If this is critical to your operations, we encourage you to submit an improvement request, which will helps us prioritize based on customer needs.

In the meantime, please rest assured that you can fully manage ALAG group members via the IdDS SCIM Groups API, and this limitation does not block your intended functionality.

entry.title: Getting Started with Unit Testing in SAP CAP Java Applications
entry.content:
Understanding Unit Testing and Test-Driven Development

Unit Testing involves verifying individual components or functions of a program in isolation to ensure they work correctly. It helps catch bugs early, supports safe code changes, and boosts overall reliability. Automated and fast, unit tests are fundamental to test-driven development and continuous integration.

Test-Driven Development (TDD) is a software development approach where we write tests before writing the actual code. We first create a failing test (Red), then write just enough code to pass it (Green), and finally refactor the code for improvement (Refactor). This cycle ensures better code quality, design, and test coverage from the start.

Benefits:

  • Catches bugs early
  • Improves code quality
  • Simplifies maintenance
  • Boosts developer confidence
  • Speeds up delivery

Getting Started with Test-Driven Development (TDD)

Consider a system with three services:
Books Service: Read-only catalog of books and authors for end users.
Orders Service: Manage orders—view, create, delete.
Admin Service: Full CRUD for products, authors, and categories.

Each service is focused on a single responsibility, making them ideal for TDD.

For detailed guidance on creating the above described SAP CAP Java application, please refer to the tutorial: https://developers.sap.com/mission.cap-java-app.html

In Test-Driven Development (TDD), we start by clearly defining the expected behaviour of a feature through test cases before writing any production code. This means we write tests that initially fail because the functionality doesn’t exist yet.

For example, when adding stock validation and reduction in the Orders Service, we begin by outlining key scenarios as test cases:

  • Book Does Not Exist: The test verifies that the system throws an error if an order contains a non-existent book.
  • Insufficient Stock: The test ensures an error is raised when the requested quantity exceeds available stock.
  • Successful Stock Update: The test confirms that stock is properly updated when the order is valid.

The test class below uses JUnit and Mockito to define above mentioned expected behaviour for the "validateBookAndDecreaseStock" method in the Orders Service.

package customer.bookstore.handlers;

import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertDoesNotThrow;
import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertEquals;
import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertThrows;
import static org.mockito.ArgumentMatchers.any;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.mock;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.times;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.verify;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.when;

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.Optional;

import org.junit.jupiter.api.BeforeEach;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;
import org.mockito.InjectMocks;
import org.mockito.Mock;
import org.mockito.MockitoAnnotations;

import com.sap.cds.Result;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnSelect;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnUpdate;
import com.sap.cds.services.ServiceException;
import com.sap.cds.services.persistence.PersistenceService;

import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrderItems;
import cds.gen.sap.capire.bookstore.Books;

class OrdersServiceTest {

	@Mock
	private PersistenceService db;

	@InjectMocks
	private OrdersService ordersService;

	@BeforeEach
	void setUp() {
		MockitoAnnotations.openMocks(this);
	}

	@Test
	void testValidateBookAndDecreaseStock_BookDoesNotExist() {
		// Arrange
		OrderItems item = OrderItems.create();
		item.setBookId("book1");
		item.setAmount(2);

		Result result = mock(Result.class);
		when(db.run(any(CqnSelect.class))).thenReturn(result);

		// Act & Assert
		ServiceException exception = assertThrows(ServiceException.class, () -> {
			ordersService.validateBookAndDecreaseStock(Arrays.asList(item));
		});

		assertEquals("Book does not exist", exception.getMessage());
	}

	@Test
	void testValidateBookAndDecreaseStock_NotEnoughStock() {
		// Arrange
		OrderItems item = OrderItems.create();
		item.setBookId("book1");
		item.setAmount(5);

		Books book = Books.create();
		book.setStock(3);

		Result result = mock(Result.class);
		when(db.run(any(CqnSelect.class))).thenReturn(result);
		when(result.first(Books.class)).thenReturn(Optional.of(book));

		// Act & Assert
		ServiceException exception = assertThrows(ServiceException.class, () -> {
			ordersService.validateBookAndDecreaseStock(Arrays.asList(item));
		});

		assertEquals("Not enough books on stock", exception.getMessage());
	}

	@Test
	void testValidateBookAndDecreaseStock_SuccessfulStockUpdate() {
		// Arrange
		OrderItems item = OrderItems.create();
		item.setBookId("book1");
		item.setAmount(2);

		Books book = Books.create();
		book.setStock(5);

		Result result = mock(Result.class);
		when(db.run(any(CqnSelect.class))).thenReturn(result);
		when(result.first(Books.class)).thenReturn(Optional.of(book));

		// Act
		assertDoesNotThrow(() -> ordersService.validateBookAndDecreaseStock(Arrays.asList(item)));

		// Assert
		assertEquals(3, book.getStock());
		verify(db, times(1)).run(any(CqnUpdate.class));
	}
	
}

Initially, the test cases will fail (as shown in the image below) as we have not implemented the functionality yet.

Now, let us make the test cases work by writing the functional logic.
The following method is implemented based on the previously defined test cases, completing the TDD cycle by writing just enough logic to make all tests pass.

package customer.bookstore.handlers;

import java.util.List;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;

import com.sap.cds.ql.Select;
import com.sap.cds.ql.Update;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnSelect;
import com.sap.cds.ql.cqn.CqnUpdate;
import com.sap.cds.services.ErrorStatuses;
import com.sap.cds.services.ServiceException;
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CqnService;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.EventHandler;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.Before;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.ServiceName;
import com.sap.cds.services.persistence.PersistenceService;

import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrderItems;
import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrderItems_;
import cds.gen.ordersservice.OrdersService_;
import cds.gen.sap.capire.bookstore.Books;
import cds.gen.sap.capire.bookstore.Books_;
@Component
@ServiceName(OrdersService_.CDS_NAME)
public class OrdersService implements EventHandler {

	private final PersistenceService db;

	OrdersService(PersistenceService db) {
		this.db = db;
	}

	@Before(event = CqnService.EVENT_CREATE, entity = OrderItems_.CDS_NAME)
	public void validateBookAndDecreaseStock(List<OrderItems> items) {
		for (OrderItems item : items) {
			String bookId = item.getBookId();
			Integer amount = item.getAmount();

			// check if the book that should be ordered is existing
			CqnSelect sel = Select.from(Books_.class).columns(b -> b.stock()).where(b -> b.ID().eq(bookId));
			Books book = db.run(sel).first(Books.class)
					.orElseThrow(() -> new ServiceException(ErrorStatuses.NOT_FOUND, "Book does not exist"));

			// check if order could be fulfilled
			int stock = book.getStock();
			if (stock < amount) {
				throw new ServiceException(ErrorStatuses.BAD_REQUEST, "Not enough books on stock");
			}

			// update the book with the new stock, means minus the order amount
			book.setStock(stock - amount);
			CqnUpdate update = Update.entity(Books_.class).data(book).where(b -> b.ID().eq(bookId));
			db.run(update);
		}
	}
}

We can now re-run the test cases to ensure the implementation satisfies all defined scenarios and that all tests pass successfully.
As per the TDD cycle, this is also the stage to refactor the code, improving readability and structure without changing behaviour.

Testing the Code Coverage
Following the implementation of the logic using the TDD methodology, code coverage has been assessed using the JaCoCo plugin, as illustrated in the image below.

Conclusion

This guide helps you in getting started with writing and organizing tests, mocking dependencies, and enhancing code reliability in SAP CAP Java applications. With these core practices in place, you're well-prepared to develop and maintain robust, testable SAP CAP Java solutions.

entry.title: 🇳🇱 Build AI services using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and Generative AI Hub
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Build AI services using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAP AI Core and Generative AI Hub. It is beneficial if you have some basic knowledge about JavaScript as we're using the SAP Cloud SDK for AI with the JavaScript variant.

This CodeJam introduces attendees to aspects of exposing generative artificial intelligence (genAI) capabilities to execute tasks using a given business context.

During this event, you'll become acquainted with the theory behind genAI, SAP AI Core, SAP AI Launchpad, and learn how to use the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model to expose AI capabilities through your own OData service.

While working through the exercises, you'll become comfortable creating CDS-based service definitions and integrating them into the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and SAP AI Core Foundation Models.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Wednesday September 03rd, 2025 in s'Hertogenbosch, Netherland 🇳🇱 from 10:00 am - 4:00 pm. The workshop site will be the Aiden office in s'Hertogenbosch. The event will be held in english.

Thanks to Aiden for hosting this event!

The instructor is the Developer Advocate @KRiedelsheimer 

Prerequisites: Any Chromium-based web browser, such as Google Chrome.

Please note that seating is limited - we can only accomodate 20 attendees. Register here in the Community Event using the RSVP functionality.

For more information on SAP CodeJam events, to ask questions, and to chat with your fellow attendees, head over to the SAP CodeJam group.

entry.title: SAP Factory Calendar Synchronization Use Case
entry.content:
Overview

In SAP implementations, the Factory Calendar (TFACD table) plays a critical role in scheduling and planning processes, particularly for manufacturing businesses with Make-to-Order (MTO) scenarios. This use case highlights the importance of timely synchronization of the Factory Calendar between SAP ECC, BW, and HANA systems to ensure accurate production scheduling and order tracking, avoiding significant business disruptions.

Business Scenario

A manufacturing organization relied on an SAP-based order tracking application to manage MTO processes. The application used SAP HANA Calculation Views and Table Functions to calculate order availability dates by combining the production order schedule finish date with goods receipt processing days, factoring in only working days as defined in the Factory Calendar (TFACD).

Challenge

In 2022, the Factory Calendar in the SAP ECC system was updated to reflect temporary changes in working days due to external circumstances, marking Fridays as non-working days (TFACD FRTAG = 0). This configuration was successfully replicated to the BW and HANA systems at the time. However, in late 2023, the organization updated the ECC Factory Calendar to reinstate Fridays as working days (TFACD FRTAG = 1). Due to an oversight, the "Transfer Global Settings" process was not executed, resulting in a discrepancy between the ECC, BW, and HANA systems.

This misalignment caused the order tracking application to inaccurately calculate order availability dates. For instance, when an availability date fell on a Thursday, the system incorrectly extended it to the following Monday, assuming Friday was a non-working day. This led to significant frustration among business users, who observed delays in order scheduling, impacting operational efficiency and customer satisfaction.

Initially, the issue was misdiagnosed as a flaw in the HANA Calculation View logic. However, thorough analysis revealed that the root cause was the failure to synchronize the updated Factory Calendar across all systems.

Solution

The issue was resolved by executing the "Transfer Global Settings" process to synchronize the Factory Calendar (TFACD) from SAP ECC to the BW and HANA systems. This action updated the working day configuration, aligning all systems with the correct schedule.

Outcome

  • Resolution Time: The synchronization process resolved the issue in approximately 10 minutes, addressing a problem that had persisted for nearly two years.
  • Business Impact: Accurate order availability dates restored user confidence in the system, improved production scheduling, and enhanced customer satisfaction.
  • Lessons Learned:
    • Timely synchronization of the Factory Calendar across SAP systems is critical for accurate scheduling and reporting.
    • Regular validation of global settings replication can prevent discrepancies in cross-system processes.
    • Collaborative root cause analysis is essential to avoid misdiagnosing issues as logic errors when they stem from configuration mismatches.

Best Practices

  1. Automate Global Settings Transfer: Schedule periodic execution of the "Transfer Global Settings" process to ensure consistency across SAP ECC, BW, and HANA systems.
  2. Monitor Factory Calendar Updates: Implement governance to track and communicate changes to the Factory Calendar, ensuring all relevant systems are updated promptly.
  3. Cross-System Validation: Perform regular checks to validate data consistency between ECC, BW, and HANA, particularly for critical tables like TFACD.
  4. User Feedback Loop: Encourage business users to report anomalies in scheduling or reporting, enabling faster identification of system discrepancies.

Conclusion

This use case underscores the importance of maintaining synchronized configurations across SAP systems to support critical business processes. By prioritizing timely updates and proactive monitoring, organizations can avoid operational disruptions, enhance system reliability, and ensure a seamless user experience.

The above mentioned use case was real life business problem encountered by the team and resolved.

entry.title: Re: BADi MRM_CHECK_INVOICE_CLOUD - can't find Transaction...
entry.content:
Refer the field RBKP-IVTYP which indicates the invoice origin type. You can use it to infer the transaction type:

  • IVTYP = '1' → Invoice
  • IVTYP = '2' → Credit Memo
  • IVTYP = '3' → Subsequent Debit
  • IVTYP = '4' → Subsequent Credit

You can access this field in BAdIs like MRM_HEADER_CHECK or INVOICE_UPDATE during MIRO processing.

If your goal is to default the correct FI Document Type, BAdI MRM_HEADER_DEFAULT allows you to set BLART based on IVTYP

entry.title: Why doesn't SAP do it alone? Unlocking SAP's Partner Ecosystem - Part 1
entry.content:
Ever wondered why SAP doesn't do it alone? Behind every successful SAP implementation lies a powerful network of specialized partners working in harmony to deliver exceptional business outcomes. From system integrators who bring your digital transformation vision to life, to ISV partners who extend SAP's capabilities with innovative solutions, the partner ecosystem is the engine that drives real-world SAP success. And this doesn't end just with SAP implementations - think about services and support or even trainings and certifications, SAP partners with a wide range of partners for various activities.

After working my entire career with two strong SAP partners and then coincidentally joining into SAP's Corporate Process & Information Technology (CPIT) -> Customer & Partner (C&P) -> E2E Partner & Ecosystem's -> Partner and Delivery Team, things started unravelling for me and I realized how less information is out there for the common masses to understand who is a partner, what are the different types of partners, etc

This is my attempt to try to document all that I have learnt in the last couple of months and in my day to day journey and I'll try to keep this as a series of blogs.

In this comprehensive overview, we'll pull back the curtain on SAP's strategic approach to partnerships, exploring why collaboration beats competition in today's complex business landscape. Discover the diverse partner types that make up this ecosystem – from consulting powerhouses to niche specialists – and learn how these relationships create value that neither SAP nor its partners could achieve independently.

Whether you're a customer navigating your SAP journey, a potential partner exploring opportunities, or simply curious about how enterprise software ecosystems operate, this deep-dive will equip you with essential insights into one of the technology industry's most sophisticated partner networks.

Ready to explore how partnerships power innovation? Let's dive in.

 

Why does SAP need "Partners"?

Consider this - say you are a new product company with one or two products in your kitty and you have a small team of people. For your initial customers, you would go and implement the solution / product yourself for the customer. Now as you scale, there will come a threshold where you won't be able to do it yourself.

What would you do in this scenario? One option would be to hire a new team, train them and let them run the implementations. 

If your product gains popularity, there could be new organizations / companies coming up that will get specifically trained in implementing your solution (you could be the ones imparting the training to them) - these are now your partner companies. You enter into an agreement with these partner companies and now they do the implementation or build new solutions / feature or say even train other companies or organizations to come onboard with this new product. 

This becomes a partner ecosystem.

Now let's come back to SAP world - With annual revenues exceeding €30 billion and a customer base spanning over 440,000 organizations across 180+ countries, SAP stands as one of the world's largest enterprise software companies. The company's portfolio encompasses everything from core ERP solutions like S/4HANA to cutting-edge technologies in AI, analytics, and cloud platforms. Yet despite this massive scale and comprehensive product suite, SAP cannot—and strategically chooses not to—handle every aspect of customer engagement directly.

While "scale factor" is one of the first and foremost reasons of expanding and taking support from partners, there is also an added reason of "strategic focus vs operational excellence". You don't want to stretch thin your teams into just the operations part of the products where you could focus the bright minds into more innovations and features.

This approach creates a win-win scenario: SAP maintains its competitive edge in product development, while partners bring specialized expertise and local market knowledge that enhances the overall customer experience. The result? Customers receive both cutting-edge technology and expert implementation support—something that would be nearly impossible for SAP to deliver alone at scale.

 

Types of SAP Partners

SELL Partners

Imagine you're looking to buy a house, but the real estate market is overwhelming - there are hundreds of properties, different neighborhoods, various price ranges, and complex financing options. You know you need a house, but you're not sure which one fits your specific needs and budget.

What do you do? You approach a trusted real estate agent who knows the local market inside out. They understand your requirements, guide you through available options, explain which properties would work best for your family size and lifestyle, and help you navigate the purchase process. Some agents can even handle the entire transaction on your behalf.

SELL Partners work exactly like real estate agents for SAP solutions. When a customer knows they need SAP services but isn't sure which specific products or configurations suit their business needs, SELL Partners step in. They have deep knowledge of SAP's entire portfolio and local market expertise. They assess the customer's requirements, recommend the right SAP solutions, and guide them through the purchase process. If they're reseller partners, customers can buy directly through them. Otherwise, they help customers purchase from SAP while earning commission for their guidance and support.

 

BUILD Partners

Picture this: you've bought a plot of land and have all the raw materials - cement, steel, bricks, pipes, electrical components - everything needed to build your dream house. You even have the architectural plans ready. But here's the problem - you don't have the construction expertise, tools, or workforce to actually build the house yourself.

What's your solution? You hire a construction company. They bring their skilled workers, project managers, and specialized equipment. They take your raw materials and blueprints and transform them into your finished home, handling everything from foundation to final touches.

BUILD Partners function as your construction team for SAP solutions. You have the SAP licenses, tools, and platforms (your raw materials), and you know what business outcomes you want to achieve (your blueprints). But you need experts to actually implement, configure, and customize these SAP solutions to meet your specific business requirements. BUILD Partners bring their technical expertise, certified consultants, and proven methodologies to transform your SAP investments into working business solutions that drive real value for your organization.

 

SERVICE Partners

Think of this scenario - you've bought a brand new car (let's say it's your SAP system), and it's running perfectly. But like any sophisticated machine, it needs regular maintenance, occasional repairs, and sometimes upgrades. You could learn to service it yourself, but that would take time away from your actual work, and you might not have the specialized skills needed.

What do you do? You take it to a trusted service center where certified mechanics handle everything - routine maintenance, troubleshooting issues, installing new features, and ensuring everything runs smoothly.

SERVICE partners work exactly like your trusted mechanics for your SAP systems. Once your SAP applications are up and running, these partners provide ongoing support, maintenance, and enhancements. They handle day-to-day issues, apply patches and updates, monitor system performance, and ensure your SAP landscape stays healthy and optimized. They're your go-to experts when something breaks or when you need to fine-tune your existing setup.

 

RUN Partners

Now imagine you're a successful business owner, but instead of buying a car, you decide it makes more sense to hire a full-time chauffeur with their own vehicle. You don't want to worry about buying, maintaining, or managing the car - you just want to get from point A to point B efficiently while you focus on running your business.

RUN Partners operate on this same principle for SAP systems. Instead of you managing your own SAP infrastructure, servers, and technical operations, RUN Partners take complete responsibility for hosting and operating your SAP environment. They provide the infrastructure, handle all the technical management, ensure security and compliance, and guarantee your systems are always available and performing optimally. You simply use the SAP applications to run your business while they handle everything behind the scenes.

Think of RUN partners as your complete SAP operations team - but external, specialized, and often more cost-effective than building this capability in-house.

 

Conclusion

Understanding these four core partner types—SELL, BUILD, SERVICE, and RUN—gives you the foundation to navigate SAP's ecosystem effectively. Whether you're a customer planning your SAP journey or a professional working within this ecosystem, knowing who does what makes all the difference in achieving successful outcomes.

The beauty of this system? It's designed around choice and specialization. You're not locked into working with one partner for everything. You might work with a SELL partner for procurement, a BUILD partner for implementation, and a RUN partner for ongoing operations—each bringing their unique strengths to your business success.

Stay tuned for the next blogs where I'll explore how these partner relationships work in practice, how to become a partner, how and where and what you should look for when selecting the right partner for your needs and many more interesting topics.

 

Reference:
  1. SAP Partners

entry.title: Re: Joule – Getting Started with Document Grounding - setup guide
entry.content:
Two things we learned the hard way:

  1. SharePoint sites created via Teams (or Teams channels) do not work
    Even though the underlying SharePoint site may appear normal, the URL path will be /teams/..., which is incompatible with this solution.

  2. Avoid special characters in your site name.
    Unfortunately, we weren’t able to create a native SharePoint site ourselves and ended up with a site that had a hyphen (-) in its name. This caused issues when trying to create a pipeline via a POST request.

    For example:

     
"name": "docu-grounding"

will result in a generic error.

You need to escape the hyphen like this:

"name": "docu\\-grounding"

Regards

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - SUM of Subtotals is not matching the Total
entry.content:
Hi all,

I'm building a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) using a live connection to an SAP HANA view. I have an issue that when results are presented for multiple Org Units the SUM of the Subtotals (for each Org Unit) is not matching the overall Totals (for all Org Units). 

The underlying data model contains daily records that could be simplified into these fields:

  • Date (attribute)
  • FTE (measure – stable over time)
  • Quota (measure – may change daily)
  • Org Unit (attribute with hierarchy)

If an Org. Unit doesn't have a Quota value for a specific day, there is no record at all for that day and the row is missing (not NULL or 0).

In SAC model I have added date hierarchy (Year-Quarter-Month) based on the Date field and created a calculated measure TotalFTE = FTE * Quota to display the TotalFTE month by month on the dashboard.

However, when aggregating TotalFTE by Org Unit at the daily level, I found that Org Units with incomplete daily records had inconsistent results as their denominator was not matching denominator of Org Units with complete daily records.

For example:

  • If Org Unit A had had records for only 15 days in a 30-day month the denominator was 15: TotalFTE(Subtotal A) = FTE*Quota/15.
  • Org. Unit B with complete records for the whole month (30 days) had the denominator as 30: TotalFTE(Subtotal B)=FTE*Quota/30.

This then resulted that the SUM of Subtotals (Subtotal A + Subtotal B) were not matching the Totals: TotalFTE(A+B)=FTE(A+B)*Quota(A+B)/30, as the denominators were not the same.

When trying to fix this, I enhanced the HANA view to include:

  • A Month column (derived from Date)
  • A CountMonthDays field (the number of calendar days in each month, e.g. 31 for March)

I then updated the SAC formula to normalize against the number of days in the month: TotalFTE = FTE * Quota / CountMonthDays to have the same denominator.

This worked well at the monthly level — Subtotals and Totals aligned correctly.

However, the problem reappears when:

  • Aggregating by Quarter or Year
  • Users apply filters for custom time ranges (e.g. Jan–May)

Since some Org Units don’t have records for every Month in the selected period, their TotalFTE is divided by fewer days due missing months (e.g. only 90 instead of 151), while the total uses the full range (e.g., 151 days), causing Subtotals ≠ Totals again.

Thanks in advance for any ideas or experience with this issue!

entry.title: FaultMessage handling in synchronous XI to REST CPI scenario
entry.content:
Hello community.

I have to implement a synchronous XI to REST scenario using Integration Suite (CPI) as the integrator.

In the SAP backend system I have a proxy consumer class with output and input structures for the request and response messages respectively. It also has a Fault Message Type structure to receive any error returned by the REST call.

The REST call is a simple HTTP GET request with some parameters.

I have implemented the REST call with a request reply external call and HTTP receiver adapter.

When the request is valid and I get a valid response from the target system, everything works fine and I get correct data in the input structure in the SAP backend proxy consumer class.

But when the request is invalid, for example one of the parameters is wrong or does not exist in the target system, the target system responses with an error captured by the HTTP receiver adapter. I'm handling this error in a exception subprocess and building correctly the fault message response, but the proxy consumer class in the SAP backend system is not receiving it correctly, the Fault Message Type structure is not populated.

In the integration engine monitor I get errors:

Inside the message, the payload is an HTMLError instead of a text/plain MainDocument and is marked as SystemError instead of ApplicationError:

Inside the HTMLError payload is the correct correct message but it seems like the proxy consumer class can not read it:

I have tried forcing the header Content-Type to 'text/plain' and 'application/xml' without success, same result on the SAP backend side.

 

What am I doing wrong or missing?

 

Thanks in advance for any help.

entry.title: Why are dimension attributes not available in Calculated Dimensions in a SAC Story?
entry.content:
Problem Statement

We are using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with a live connection to an Analytic Model (AM) created on top of a Fact Table  in SAP Datasphere.

We observed that:

  • When trying to create Calculated Dimensions within the SAC , only keys and columns from the Fact Table are available.
  • Attributes from associated Dimension Tables are not visible for use in formula expressions inside Calculated Dimensions.
  • However, those same attributes can be displayed in SAC stories without issue.

In below example only keys and dimension attributes from FACT are available and not all the attributes from the Dimension tables joined with FACT -

 

Question:

Why are dimension attributes (from Dimension Tables joined with FACT) not available in Calculated Dimensions, even though they appear in the SAC story view?

In my opinion, this behavior is due to the live connection architecture and how SAC interprets model metadata from Datasphere:

  1. SAC only allows calculated logic (e.g., Calculated Dimensions) to reference fields that are part of the Analytic Model schema.

  2. When the AM is built directly on a Fact Table/View, it only includes the foreign keys, not the descriptive attributes of related dimensions.

  3. In a live connection, SAC pushes all calculation logic to Datasphere, so fields must be explicitly present in the underlying dataset or view for them to be available in formulas.

To make dimension attributes available in Calculated Dimensions within SAC, we have used Graphical Views with Explicit Joins

  • In Datasphere, created a Graphical View where we joined the dimension tables to the Fact Table using foreign keys.

  • This exposed both keys and attributes in the resulting Analytic Model, making them available in SAC for both display and calculations.
  • With this approach we can see all the attributes also from Dimension Tables/Views in a Calculated Dimension Formula.

 

 

Is this the correct approach? or is there alternative approach?

Can we avoid using Graphical Views (with explicit joins) and still access all necessary attributes for calculated logic?

How to check DB core allocation and DB storage?

entry.title: Re: How to check collective resource allocation on Commer...
entry.content:
In order to check check collective resource allocation on environment you can access dedicated dashboard in Dynatrace "SAP - Infra Usage" which displays total RAM/CPU requested as well as DB Compute and DB storage. It also displays data splitted per service. 

It is described in more details in following article: 3583365 - How to check the average resources usage in Dynatrace
